facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 578 of 1961 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 578 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and decree dated March 12, 1959 of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 685 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 12, 1959. of the Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 685 of 1956.

facts.text: High Court judgment dated March 12, 1959 reversed the order of the Bombay Civil Court judge passed in Chamber Summons in Arbitration case No. A.B.N. C.H.O.-2310/88 of 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: dated March 12,1959, reversing those of the judge of the Bombay Civil Court, passed in Chamber Summons, in Arbitration case No. A.B.N. C.H.O.-2310/88 of 1954-55.

facts.text: Happy Home Cooperative Housing Society Ltd was registered in February 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The Happy Home Cooperative Housing Society Ltd -- hereinafter referred to as the Society was registered in February 1949.

facts.text: Society obtained a lease of land measuring about 12 thousand sq. yards at Nehru Road, Vile Parle East, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: It obtained a lease of a piece of land measuring about 12 thousand sq. yards situate at Nehru Road, Vile Parle  East  Bombay.

facts.text: Society divided the land into 17 plots for allotment to members for building purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The Society divided this land into 17 plots to be allotted to each one of its members for building purposes.

facts.text: Plot No. 10 measuring about 676 sq. yds. was allotted to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: Accordingly, Plot. No. 10, measuring about 676 sq. yds. was allotted to the appellant, and other plots were similarly allotted

facts.text: Appellant constructed a house on his plot through the agency of the Society and occupied the building on or about May 1, 1951.

anchor.surface_text: Through the agency of the Society, the appellant companystructed a house on his plot. The companystruction was companypleted and the appellant occupied

facts.text: Society advanced a loan of Rs. 26,922/- odd to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 26,922/- odd was advanced by way of loan, to the appellant.

facts.text: Agreement dated March 26, 1952 entered into between appellant and Society regarding the loan, registered on May 27, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: An agreement dated March 26, 1952 was entered into between the appellant and the Society in respect of the loan aforesaid, and the document was duly registered on May 27, 1952.

facts.text: Agreement provided for repayment of loan in 366 or smaller monthly instalments, after which Society would execute sub-lease of Plot No. 10 to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The agreement between the appellant and the Society provided that the amount of loan aforesaid advanced to the appellant should be repaid in 366 or smaller monthly instalments and after the entire amount

facts.text: In event of default in payment of instalment, Society could determine agreement, forfeit amounts paid, and require surrender of property.

anchor.surface_text: It was further stipulated that in the event of default in the payment of an instalment, fixed in the agreement, the Society had the right to determine the agreement and thereupon any amounts already paid

facts.text: No instalment was paid by the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that numberinstalment was paid by the appellant with the result that on August 26, 1954, the Society gave numberice to him

facts.text: Society gave notice to appellant on August 26, 1954 to give vacant possession, but appellant did not comply.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that numberinstalment was paid by the appellant with the result that on August 26, 1954, the Society gave numberice to him, calling upon him to give vacant possession of the premises, but the appellant did number companyply

facts.text: Society referred dispute to Registrar under s. 54 of Bombay Co-operative Societies Act (Bombay Act VII of 1925).

anchor.surface_text: In view of the persistent refusal of the appellant to companyply with the terms of the agreement, the Society referred to dispute with the appellant under s. 54 of the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act

facts.text: Dispute heard and decided by Committee of Arbitrators appointed by Registrar, consisting of nominee of Society, nominee of appellant, and nominee of Registrar as Chairman.

anchor.surface_text: The said dispute was heard and decided by a Committee of Arbitrators, appointed by the Registrar, Co operative Societies, companysisting of three gentlemen.  1  a numberinee of the Society as plaintiff,  2  numberinee of the Appellant

facts.text: Committee of Arbitration by majority awarded in favour of Society: appellant to deliver vacant possession of Plot No. 10 and house, pay Rs. 150/- per month compensation from October 1, 1954, and bear costs.

anchor.surface_text: The said Committee of Arbitration, by majority, gave an award in favour of the Society to the effect that the appellant do deliver vacan possession of Plot, No. 10, alongwith the house, to the Society and pay Rs. 150/- per month

facts.text: Appellant filed revisional application to Bombay Co-operative Tribunal contending dispute was landlord-tenant matter under s.28 Rent Control Act, jurisdiction with Small Causes Court.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant made a revisional application to the Bombay Co-operative Tribunal, companytending that the dispute between the Society and himself was essentially a dispute between landlord and tenant

facts.text: Bombay Co-operative Tribunal dismissed the revisional application.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the parties, the Tribunal negatived the companytention raised on behalf of the appellant and dismissed the revisional application.

facts.text: Award certified under s.59 of the Act and filed in Bombay City Civil Court for execution.

anchor.surface_text: After the Award was certified under s. 59 of the Act, the Award was filed in the Bombay City Civil Court for execution.

facts.text: Appellant took out Chamber Summons against Society for stay of execution.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant took out a Chamber Summons against the Society for stay of the execution proceedings.

facts.text: Bombay Civil Court judge held award without jurisdiction under s.28 Rent Control Act and made summons absolute on October 16, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judge who heard the Chamber Summons held that the Award made by the Arbitrators was without jurisdiction, in view of the provisions of s. 28 of the Rent Control Act. Accordingly, the summons was made absolute on October 16, 1956.

facts.text: Society appealed to Bombay High Court in First Appeal No. 685 of 1956.

anchor.surface_text: From that order the Society came up in appeal to the High companyrt.

facts.text: High Court held the agreement of March 26, 1952 was only an agreement to lease, no landlord-tenant relationship, set aside lower court order, directed execution of award with costs to Society.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, on a companysideration of the terms of the agreement aforesaid, of March 26, 1952, and after elaborate arguments raised by the parties as to the legal effect of that document came to the companyclusion that it was only an agreement to lease...

facts.text: Appeal to Supreme Court brought on certificate granted by High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is from this judgment and order that this appeal has been brought to this Court, on a certificate being granted by the High Court.

facts.text: Society's lease of land was for 999 years from March 17, 1950 at annual rent of Rs. 6,264/- .

anchor.surface_text: The preamble also mentions the fact that the Society itself had taken a lease of the entire open piece of land, of which plot No. 10 was a part, for a term of 999 years from March 17, 1950, at the annual rent of Rs. 6,264/- .

facts.text: Appellant made no payment of any instalment.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been companytested on behalf of the appellant that he did number pay any instalment in respect of the transaction in his favour.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no landlord-tenant relationship existed between appellant and Society under the agreement.

issues.text: The main question in controversy in this case is whether the Award made under the Act, which became a decree of the Civil Court, under the certificate of the Registrar under s. 59, was without jurisdiction, and, therefore, incapable of execution.

anchor.surface_text: The main question in controversy in this case is whether the Award made under the Act, which became a decree of the Civil Court, under the certificate of the Registrar under s. 59, was without jurisdiction, and, therefore, incapable of execution.

issues.text: whether the appellant was a tenant under the Society, by virtue of the agreement aforesaid of March 26, 1952.

anchor.surface_text: whether the appellant was a tenant under the Society, by virtue of the agreement aforesaid of March 26, 1952. If it is held that the agreement aforesaid did not create the relationship of landlord and tenant, but that the appellant continued to be the debtor of the Society until all the outstanding amount advanced to him in respect of the plot and the structure had been liquidated, the Rent Control Act, and s. 28 thereof, will be out of the way of the parties.

issues.text: whether the agreement of March 26, 1952 created the relationship of landlord and tenant between the parties.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that the real nature of a transaction has to be determined on a proper construction of the document as a whole and not upon any particular words used in the document. The agreement construed as a whole leaves no manner of doubt that it was an agreement between the appellant and the Society to grant a sub-lease of Plot No. 10 only after the appellant had fulfilled his part of the agreement, namely, had paid all the outstanding amounts due to the Society in respect of the premium on the plot, the amounts advanced for construction of the house and the interest accrued due until the entire amount had been liquidated.

issues.text: by virtue of s. 28 of Bombay Act 57 of 1947 the Committee of arbitrators appointed under the Bombay Cooperative Societies Act 7 of 1925 had no jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the question whether the appellant was a tenant of the premises of the society.

anchor.surface_text: But the appellant contended that whatever view we may take of the relation created by the document, by virtue of s. 28 of Bombay Act 57 of 1947 the Committee of arbitrators appointed under the Bombay Cooperative Societies Act 7 of 1925 had no jurisdiction to adjudicate upon the question whether the appellant was a tenant of the premises of the society, and reliance in that behalf was placed upon the judgment of this Court in Babulal Bhuramal v. Nandram Shivram.

issues.text: even if the Society claimed to obtain an order for possession on some footing other than the relationship of landlord and tenant, when the appellant raised the contention that he was a tenant and the relationship of landlord and tenant was put into issue, the Court of Small Causes, Bombay, alone was competent to decide that question.

anchor.surface_text: Alternatively, it was contended that even if the Society claimed to obtain an order for possession on some footing other than the relationship of landlord and tenant, when the appellant raised the contention that he was a tenant and the relationship of landlord and tenant was put into issue, the Court of Small Causes, Bombay, alone was competent to decide that question.

issues.text: whether the provisions of s. 28 of Bombay Act 57 of 1947 override the provisions of the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act 7 of 1925.

anchor.surface_text: No useful purpose will therefore be served by entering upon a discussion whether the provisions of s. 28 of Bombay Act 57 of 1947 override the provisions of the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act 7 of 1925, as was suggested at the Bar.

arguments.claim: The dispute between the Society and appellant is essentially a landlord-tenant dispute regarding possession and recovery of rent, so only Small Causes Court has jurisdiction under s.28 of Rent Control Act.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant made a revisional application to the Bombay Co-operative Tribunal, contending that the dispute between the Society and himself was essentially a dispute between landlord and tenant regarding the possession of the premises and the recovery of rent and that the only Court that had jurisdiction to decide such a controversy was the Small Causes Court in Greater Bombay, in view of s. 28 of the Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rents Control Act Bombay Act 57 of 1947 .

The agreement construed as a whole leaves no manner of doubt that it was an agreement between the appellant and the Society to grant a sub-lease of Plot No. 10 only after the appellant had fulfilled his part of the agreement,

arguments.claim: Society did not claim L-T before arbitrators; relief on basis of loan default and membership cessation.

anchor.surface_text: But there is no warrant for the submission that the Society claimed before the arbitrators that the appellant was a tenant and on that basis claimed relief for possession.

arguments.claim: Defendant's plea of tenancy does not oust jurisdiction of forum invoked by plaintiff if plaintiff does not set up L-T.

anchor.surface_text: Where the person so invoking does not set up the claim that the other party is a tenant or a landlord the defendant is not entitled to displace the jurisdiction of the ordinary court by an allegation that he stands in that relation qua the other and on that ground the Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit or proceeding or an application.

arguments.claim: Babulal Bhuramal case does not support that defendant's tenancy plea displaces jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The agreement dated March 26, 1952 did not create the relationship of landlord and tenant between the appellant and the Society; it was merely an executory contract to grant a sub-lease upon full repayment of the loan and fulfillment of conditions.

anchor.surface_text: It is well-settled that the real nature of a transaction has to be determined on a proper construction of the document as a whole and not upon any particular words used in the document. The agreement construed as a whole leaves no manner of doubt that it was an agreement between the appellant and the Society to grant a sub-lease of Plot No. 10 only after the appellant had fulfilled his part of the agreement,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Document construed as whole; reference to 'tenant' is mere description; sub-lease conditional on payment of all dues including consent of mortgagee Government.

holdings.text: The description of the appellant as 'tenant' in the agreement is a mere description or misdescription and does not create landlord-tenant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the High Court is entirely correct in taking the view that was a mere description, or misdescription, of the appellant and that, in law, the appellant could not claim that relationship of landlord and tenant had been created

holdings.reasoning_summary: Real nature determined by proper construction of entire document, not isolated words or labels.

holdings.text: The Award made by the Committee of Arbitrators under the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act was valid and within jurisdiction, and capable of execution.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No landlord-tenant relationship, so s.28 Rent Act inapplicable; dispute over loan default and membership within coop jurisdiction.

holdings.text: The Society did not claim before the arbitrators that the appellant was a tenant or seek possession on landlord-tenant footing; claim based on loan default and cessation of membership.

anchor.surface_text: Before the Committee of arbitrators the Society had alleged that the appellant had made persistent defaults in repayment of the loan due by him and had claimed a declaration that the appellant had ceased to be a member

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pleadings and award show claim on default under agreement, not tenancy.

holdings.text: Appellant's plea that he was a tenant does not oust jurisdiction of arbitrators under Coop Act, as Society did not invoke landlord-tenant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: It was, it appears, not alleged that any relation of landlord and tenant had ever subsisted between the Society and the appellant, and the plea of the appellant that he was a tenant in respect of the premises in dispute could not affect the jurisdiction of the Committee of arbitrators.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Jurisdiction depends on plaintiff's claim; defendant's defensive plea does not displace.

holdings.text: Exclusive jurisdiction under s.28 Rent Act arises only if plaintiff alleges landlord-tenant relationship; defendant's allegation does not displace jurisdiction of forum invoked by plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Where the person so invoking does not set up the claim that the other party is a tenant or a landlord the defendant is not entitled to displace the jurisdiction of the ordinary court by an allegation that he stands in that relation qua the other and on that ground the Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit or proceeding or an application.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.28 applies to suits where relationship claimed by party invoking jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Babulal Bhuramal v. Nandram Shivram does not support proposition that defendant's plea of tenancy ousts jurisdiction of ordinary courts.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent concerns plaintiff claiming tenancy against denying landlord; distinguishable.

holdings.text: No need to decide whether s.28 Rent Act overrides Bombay Co-operative Societies Act.

anchor.surface_text: No useful purpose will therefore be served by entering upon a discussion whether the provisions of s. 28 of Bombay Act 57 of 1947 override the provisions of the Bombay Co-operative Societies Act 7 of 1925, as was suggested at the Bar.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue not reached as s.28 inapplicable on facts.

anchor.surface_text: Where the person so invoking does not set up the claim that the other party is a tenant or a landlord the defendant is not entitled to displace the jurisdiction of the ordinary court by an allegation that he stands in that relation qua the other and on that ground the Court has no jurisdiction to try the suit or proceeding or an application.

The Award was, therefore, a perfectly valid Award and there was absolutely no justification for the plea taken by the appellant that he was a tenant who was governed by the provisions of the Rent Control Act Bombay Act 57 of 1947 . But the appellant contended that whatever view we may take
